### Bus Ridership Analysis

------------------------------------------------------------------------

#### Create a vector s1 whose elements correspond to the number of passengers who can possibly get on board the bus at a particular stop

```{r}
s1 = c(0, 1, 2)
```

#### Create a vector p1 whose elements correspond to the respective chances of the number of passengers identified in the previous question getting on board the bus at a particular stop.

```{r}
p1 =c(0.5,0.4,0.1)
```

#### Create a 2x10-matrix P such that the jth column of this matrix should have a passenger on the busâ€™s continuing-on and getting-off chances for the jth stop for j = 1, . . . , 10.

# 2,3,8,,9,10

```{r}
P = matrix(c(0.8, 0.2, 0.2, 0.8, 0.8, 0.8, 0.8, 0.2,0.2,0.0, 0.2,0.8,0.8,
0.2, 0.2, 0.2, 0.2, 0.8, 0.8, 1.0), nrow=2, ncol=10, byrow =T)
rownames(P) = c('Continuing', 'Departing')
#colnames(P) = c('S1', 'S2', 'S3', S4, 'S5', 'S6', 'S7', 'S8', 'S9', 'S10')
colnames(P) = paste0('Stop', c(1:10))
print(P)
```

#### Create a vector s2 whose elements correspond to the encoded versions of a passenger staying

on the bus and getting off of the bus at a particular stop, respectively.

```{r}
s2 <- c(0, 1)
names(s2) = c('Staying', 'Departing')
print(s2)
```

#### Simulate the number of passengers at the last stop

```{r}
n = 30 # zero passengers in the bus at stop-1
for (j in c(1:9)){
  if (n > 0){
    n = n - sum(sample(s2, size = n, replace = T, prob = P[, j]))
  }
  n = n + sample(s1, size = 1, prob = p1)
  cat(sprintf('No. of passenger after stop-%d = %d\n', j, n))
}
```
